awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Uncertainty Quantification of Structural Systems: Generalized Information Theory
awd_abstract_narration:
Uncertainty is inherent in the assessment and prediction of the performance of structures and community infrastructure when evaluating risk, hazard mitigation and vulnerability/resiliency. Structural engineering needs to reflect multi-disciplinary societal issues, including social, political and economic, which introduce partial knowledge and disparate characteristics of uncertainty. While traditional probabilistic methods to treat the uncertainty can address partial and dissimilar information, they are not the most appropriate for comprehensive incorporation of broader contexts reflecting sources such as expert judgement and imprecision. This EArly-concept Grant for Exploratory Research (EAGER) project undertakes exploratory research on the broader aspects of uncertainty approaches to structural engineering safety, incorporating multi-attribute aspects of judgement and unpredictability in human decision-making. The research introduces varied sources of uncertainty into structural design, melding this with community issues that assess the value of the structure to economic, environmental and social/political sustainability. Quantitative and linguistic uncertainties are incorporated under a comprehensive design philosophy capable of handling vagueness, and ambiguity. These broadened approaches to structural engineering and community performance will lead to great benefits to society through enhancements of the built environment. 

The primary objective of this project is the development of methods under the umbrella of Generalized Information Theory that expand traditional probabilistic approaches to structural and community safety, enhancing the treatment of uncertainty by incorporating notions of ignorance, interactivity, and linguistic information. The scope of the project includes generalization of probability theory with uncertainty measures based on monotone theory and incorporating linguistic vagueness, ambiguity, evidence concepts (belief and plausibility), conflicting expert judgement, imprecision, partial knowledge, confidence, and subjective possibility. An initial application in this exploratory project will be for earthquake damage estimation and vulnerability assessment. With actual community data, fuzzy pattern recognition will be used to investigate the existence of building damage patterns and potential seismic vulnerability prediction.

por.por_cntn:
Uncertainty is inherent in the areas of risk, hazard mitigation and community vulnerability/resilience. Increasingly, infrastructure decisions need to reflect multiple issues of society, including social, political, economic and cross-disciplinary factors. This complex interaction leads to challenging issues regarding information/partial knowledge and disparate characteristics of uncertainty from different sources. In such complex engineering situations, the use of expert opinion plays a valuable role. Traditionally, the formal mathematical treatment used to combine opinions from multiple experts is through probabilistic analysis, but it is often more suitable to use Generalized Information Theory (GIT). GIT is based on precepts of basic evidence assignment, which allows for evidence on multiple events (rather than just singletons from probability theory) and the specific inclusion of ignorance. This project investigated the use of evidence theory for combing expert opinion in the case of seismic damage to structures. A survey was developed and disseminated to demonstrate that evidence theory results gave more accurate assessments to actual ground-verified building damage. The project also derived heretofore unknown convergence theories for combining expert beliefs, including surprising behavior that supports the use of evidence theory as well as caveats to be explored. The project led to three conference papers and two journal papers.

Intellectual merit

Methods under the umbrella of Generalized Information Theory (GIT) expand traditional probability approaches, enhancing the treatment of uncertainty by incorporating notions of ignorance, interactivity, and linguistic information. Mathematical explorations of GIT, and the role of ignorance when combining expert opinions were valuable contributions from this project. Suggestions for the role of GIT, and the call for further investigations, were developed to improve the knowledge and understanding for structural safety decision-makers, leading to more consistent and informed decisions. Results indicate that probability may not be the most natural framework to quantitatively incorporate uncertainty in these situations.

Broader Impacts

The broader impacts of this exploratory research have been truly exciting: the opportunity to bring about a completely new way of introducing varied sources of uncertainty into structural design, and the melding of this with community issues that assess the value of the structure to economic, environmental and economic/social/political sustainability. Disparate sources of quantitative and linguistic uncertainty can be incorporated under a design philosophy umbrella capable of handling vagueness, ambiguity and confidence.
